intro: Sisymbrium lasiocalyx, commonly known as the hairy mustard, is a flowering plant belonging to the Brassicaceae family. It is native to regions of Europe and Asia, often found in disturbed soils and along roadsides. The plant features small, yellow flowers arranged in racemes, and its leaves are typically lobed and hairy, giving it its common name. Sisymbrium lasiocalyx produces small, pod-like fruits that contain several seeds, which are dispersed by wind. It is an annual plant that thrives in temperate climates and is sometimes considered a weed in agricultural settings.
